title: 107_hr762
content: The "North American Slavery Memorial Council Act" establishes the North American Slavery Memorial Council to design, construct, and operate a national memorial and museum in honor of victims of slavery in North America. The Council's duties include establishing a suitable site in Washington D.C. for the Memorial and Museum. The Council shall consist of 65 voting members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate, as well as 3 nonvoting members appointed by the Secretaries of Interior, State, and Education. The Council members are appointed for 5-year terms, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. If a member appointed from Congress ceases to be a member, they can continue for up to 60 days. Members of the Council are appointed for 5-year terms, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. A member, except for 5 members of the House of Representatives and 5 members of the Senate, may serve after the term expires until a successor takes office. Members are paid at the daily equivalent of the maximum annual rate of basic pay under title 5 for each day of duty. Full-time federal employees or Members of Congress serving on the Council may not receive additional compensation. Each member also receives travel expenses. The Council members receive travel expenses, including per diem, in accordance with specific regulations. One-third of the members constitute a quorum for meetings, which must be held at least monthly. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are appointed by the President for 5-year terms, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF. The Council shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding the maximum rate of basic pay under title 5. The Director can appoint additional staff with Council approval and hire experts and consultants at specified rates. Federal agencies may detail staff to the Council upon request. The head of any Federal department or agency may detail personnel to the Council on a reimbursable basis to assist in carrying out its duties under this Act. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Council has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Council. The Council can accept gifts, bequests, and devises to aid its work, with funds deposited in the Treasury for disbursement. The Council has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, or devises, which will be considered as a gift to the United States. They can use the United States mails and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services for their responsibilities under this Act. SEC. 7. MEMORIAL AND MUSEUM. The Council determines architectural design of the Memorial and Museum with approval from the Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the National Capital Planning Commission. The Council can acquire real property in the District of Columbia for the Memorial and Museum with approval from the Secretary of the Interior, following specific procedures. The Council may acquire real property in the District of Columbia for the Memorial and Museum, either through transfer from the government or purchase with owner consent. The Council is responsible for constructing and operating the Memorial and Museum according to approved architectural design, bylaws, and annual budgets. The Council can acquire artifacts and property for the Memorial and Museum, establish policies for collections utilization, educational programs, exhibitions, and research projects related to slavery in North America. They can also collaborate with institutions for educational programs and support their efforts in promoting understanding of slavery in North America. The Council is responsible for acquiring artifacts and property for the Memorial and Museum, establishing policies for collections utilization, educational programs, exhibitions, and research projects related to slavery in North America. They also collaborate with institutions to promote understanding of slavery in North America and maintain insurance on the Memorial and Museum. They also collaborate with institutions to promote understanding of slavery in North America and maintain insurance on the Memorial and Museum. The Comptroller General audits the financial transactions of the Council when requested by Congress. The Council must submit an annual report to Congress on its activities and financial transactions involving donated funds. The Memorial and Museum is not considered a commemorative work under the Commemorative Works Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided. SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums authorized for carrying out the Act. Appropriated amounts for Council cannot be used for construction but can be used for operation only if funds received under section 6(c) are equal to or greater. Spending authority in the Act effective only as provided in appropriation Acts.
